sn16.10:4.2: At one time Venerable Mahākassapa was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
sn16.10:4.3: Then Venerable Ānanda got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went to Mahākassapa
sn16.10:4.5: “Kassapa, come, sir. Let’s go to one of the nuns’ quarters.”
sn16.10:4.6: “You go, Reverend Ānanda. You have many duties and responsibilities.”
sn16.10:4.10: And a third time, Ānanda said:
sn16.10:4.11: “Kassapa, come, sir. Let’s go to one of the nuns’ quarters.”
sn16.10:5.1: Then Venerable Mahākassapa got dressed in the morning and, taking his bowl and robes, went with Venerable Ānanda as his second monk to one of the nuns’ quarters,
sn16.10:5.2: where he sat on the indicated seat.
sn16.10:5.3: And then several nuns went up to Mahākassapa,
sn16.10:5.4: bowed, and sat down to one side.
sn16.10:5.5: Mahākassapa educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired those nuns with a Dharma talk,
sn16.10:5.6: after which he got up from his seat and left.
sn16.10:6.1: Then the nun Thullatissā was upset and blurted out:
sn16.10:6.2: “What is Master Mahākassapa thinking, that he’d teach Dhamma in front of Master Ānanda, the Videhan sage?
sn16.10:6.3: He’s like a needle seller who thinks they can sell a needle to a needle maker!”
sn16.10:7.1: Mahākassapa heard Thullatissā say these words,
sn16.10:7.3: “Is that right, Reverend Ānanda? Am I the needle seller and you the needle maker?
sn16.10:7.4: Or am I the needle maker and you the needle seller?”
sn16.10:7.5: “Forgive her, sir. The woman’s a fool.”
sn16.10:7.6: “Hold on, Reverend Ānanda! Don’t make the Saṅgha investigate you further!
sn16.10:8.1: What do you think, Reverend Ānanda? Was it you who the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:
sn16.10:8.2: ‘Mendicants, whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
sn16.10:9.1: “I was the one the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:
sn16.10:9.2: ‘Mendicants, whenever I want, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, I enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
sn16.10:9.5: (The nine progressive meditations and the five insights should be treated in full.)
sn16.10:10.1: What do you think, Reverend Ānanda? Was it you who the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:
sn16.10:10.2: ‘I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And I live having achieved it with my own insight due to the end of defilements.
sn16.10:11.1: “I was the one the Buddha brought up before the Saṅgha of mendicants, saying:
sn16.10:11.2: ‘I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And I live having achieved it with my own insight due to the end of defilements.
sn16.10:12.1: Reverend, you might as well think to hide a bull elephant that’s three or three and a half meters tall behind a palm leaf as to hide my six insights.”
sn16.10:13.1: But the nun Thullatissā fell from the spiritual life.
